channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Cities are being destroyed. California clearly isn't as enlightened about race as we think
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: That these violent uprisings and peaceful protests are happening all over California speaks to something black people know well and others ignore.
item.content:encoded: That these violent uprisings and peaceful protests are happening all over California speaks to something black people know well and others ignore.

media:content.media:description: Santa Monica, CA, Sunday May 31, 2020 - Protestors face off with police downtown as unrest continues in the wake of the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: What time are the curfews in and around L.A. tonight?
item.dc:creator: Jessica Roy
item.description: Curfew times vary from city to city in Los Angeles County. Here is where things stand.
item.content:encoded: Curfew times vary from city to city in Los Angeles County. Here is where things stand.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 31: The California National Guard is deployed at City Hall in downtown Los Angeles on Sunday, May 31, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Correctional health officials aim to test all L.A. County inmates for coronavirus by next week
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Correctional health officials say they plan to finish coronavirus testing of all inmates held in Los Angeles County jails by next week.
item.content:encoded: Correctional health officials say they plan to finish coronavirus testing of all inmates held in Los Angeles County jails by next week.

media:content.media:description: An inmate at Men's Central Jail. A San Diego court has ruled that Prop. 47 also applies to juvenile offenders.
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Newsom urges peace as George Floyd's death ignites protests by day, violence by night
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom urges peace at a news conference Monday and seeks to calm anger in California over the death of George Floyd.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom urges peace at a news conference Monday and seeks to calm anger in California over the death of George Floyd.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his revised 2019-2020 state budget during a news conference Thursday, May 9, 2019, in Sacramento, Calif. Newsom, a Democrat, has proposed a $213.5 billion a spending plan. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: Blacks' 'lifetime of stress' hits tipping point as coronavirus and protests converge, Ferrer says
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Public health officials continued to warn that the virus has not changed, despite eased restrictions allowing some businesses to reopen and larger gatherings to take place.
item.content:encoded: Public health officials continued to warn that the virus has not changed, despite eased restrictions allowing some businesses to reopen and larger gatherings to take place.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 30: Protesters in the Fairfax District on Saturday, May 30, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Protests erupted across the country, with people outraged over the death of George Floyd, a black man killed after a white Minneapolis police officer pinned him to the ground with his knee. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: After George Floyd's death, California schools chief vows to address bias
item.dc:creator: Sonali Kohli
item.description: After George Floyd protests, the California Department of Education will focus more on addressing implicit bias in classrooms, Tony Thurmond said.
item.content:encoded: After George Floyd protests, the California Department of Education will focus more on addressing implicit bias in classrooms, Tony Thurmond said.

media:content.media:description: Alexys Davis, who was taking graduation photos at the San Diego County Administration Building was cheered on by protesters on May 31, 2020. The group was protesting the death of George Floyd.
media:content.media:credit: K.C. Alfred/K.C. Alfred/The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: South Coast Plaza postpones reopening as protests, looting rock California
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The upscale mall in Costa Mesa had planned to throw open its doors to customers Monday following a lengthy coronavirus-related closure but will remain closed indefinitely.
item.content:encoded: The upscale mall in Costa Mesa had planned to throw open its doors to customers Monday following a lengthy coronavirus-related closure but will remain closed indefinitely.

media:content.media:description: COSTA MESA, CA -- MAY 15: Customers waiting in the return queue, receive instruction from a Nordstrom employee at curbside pickup outside Nordstrom at South Coast Plaza on Friday, May 15, 2020, in Costa Mesa, CA. South Coast Plaza has joined the list of outlets offering contact-free pickup for customers amid the coronavirus pandemic. Customers remain in their auto while their items are put in their car's trunk. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: National Guard arrives in Sacramento, as protests, mayhem rage in much of the Bay Area
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria, Stuart Leavenworth
item.description: Protesters took to the streets again Sunday night in response to the death of George Floyd, but interspersed with peaceful marchers were groups intent on vandalism and stealing.
item.content:encoded: Protesters took to the streets again Sunday night in response to the death of George Floyd, but interspersed with peaceful marchers were groups intent on vandalism and stealing.

media:content.media:description: A man jumps on a vandalized CHP squad car in Oakland on Sunday during another night of demonstrations against the killing of two unarmed black men by police in Ferguson, Mo., and New York.

item.title: First California prison officer dies after contracting coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Danny Mendoza, the first California prison officer to die after contracting coronavirus, worked at the California Rehabilitation Center in Norco.
item.content:encoded: Danny Mendoza, the first California prison officer to die after contracting coronavirus, worked at the California Rehabilitation Center in Norco.

media:content.media:description: Staff from the California Rehabilitation Center, California Highway Patrol, Riverside County Fire Department and coroner's office and the Corona fire and police departments held a vehicle procession Saturday to honor Correctional Officer Danny Mendoza, 53, who died after being diagnosed with the coronavirus.
media:content.media:credit: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

item.title: 'We lost everything in 10 minutes': Santa Monica merchants survey what's left after looting
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde, Melissa Etehad
item.description: The looting hit large chain businesses like Vans, Vons, banks and other retailers in and around the Santa Monica Place mall. But small business owners also were targeted.
item.content:encoded: The looting hit large chain businesses like Vans, Vons, banks and other retailers in and around the Santa Monica Place mall. But small business owners also were targeted.

media:content.media:description: Santa Monica, CA, Sunday May 31, 2020 - A police officer inspects the damage to a Vons supermarket hours after it was looted. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD officers shoot woman after fatal stabbing in Hollywood
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Authorities said the woman who was shot in Hollywood was stabbing another woman, who ultimately died in the attack.
item.content:encoded: Authorities said the woman who was shot in Hollywood was stabbing another woman, who ultimately died in the attack.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles police officers shot and wounded a woman after they allegedly found her stabbing another person to death.

item.title: Long Beach police swamped by looting; National Guard arrives
item.dc:creator: Ruben Vives
item.description: While hundreds in Long Beach demonstrated against the police killing of George Floyd, a separate group began robbing stores in the Pike Outlets a block away.
item.content:encoded: While hundreds in Long Beach demonstrated against the police killing of George Floyd, a separate group began robbing stores in the Pike Outlets a block away.

media:content.media:description: LONG BEACH CALIF. - MAY 31, 2020. Looters ransack a strip mall at the intersection of Seventh Street and Long Beach Boulevard in Long Beach on Sunday, May 31, 2020. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Climbing out from coronavirus: Northern California county sags under weight of economic crash
item.dc:creator: Joe Mozingo
item.description: Their remoteness hasn't spared them from the economic fallout of the shutdown. And the sparsity of COVID-19 cases in this Northern California county has only made the restrictive measures hobbling their livelihoods all the more exasperating.
item.content:encoded: Their remoteness hasn't spared them from the economic fallout of the shutdown. And the sparsity of COVID-19 cases in this Northern California county has only made the restrictive measures hobbling their livelihoods all the more exasperating.

media:content.media:description: GRASS VALLEY, CA-MAY 22, 2020: Lisa Shippers, center, owner of Old Town Cafe in Grass Valley, talks with Grass Valley residents Sabrina Hocking, 31, left, and her mother, Judith Hocking, 63, as they wait for their breakfast to arrive. The cafe fully re-opened on May 13, previously doing curbside only pick-up due to the coronavirus outbreak. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Thousands of immigrants are stuck in ICE centers. Getting out depends on the judge
item.dc:creator: Andrea Castillo
item.description: In response to lawsuits and public pressure, ICE has released hundreds of immigrants from detention facilities. Others have been released after paying bond.
item.content:encoded: In response to lawsuits and public pressure, ICE has released hundreds of immigrants from detention facilities. Others have been released after paying bond.

media:content.media:description: ADELANTO, CA - NOVEMBER 15: A guard escorts an immigrant detainee from his 'segregation cell' back into the general population at the Adelanto Detention Facility on November 15, 2013 in Adelanto, California. Most detainees in segregation cells are sent there for fighting with other immigrants, according to guards. The facility, the largest and newest Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), detention center in California, houses an average of 1,100 immigrants in custody pending a decision in their immigration cases or awaiting deportation. The average stay for a detainee is 29 days. The facility is managed by the private GEO Group. ICE detains an average of 33,000 undocumented immigrants in more than 400 facilities nationwide. (Photo by John Moore/Getty Images)

item.title: LAPD focused on peaceful protesters while ignoring looting, business owners say
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector, Richard Winton
item.description: Despite efforts by the mayor and police chief to strike the right tone in their response to the protests over the death of George Floyd, many in Los Angeles say they missed the mark.
item.content:encoded: Despite efforts by the mayor and police chief to strike the right tone in their response to the protests over the death of George Floyd, many in Los Angeles say they missed the mark.

media:content.media:description: Santa Monica, CA, Sunday May 31, 2020 - Looters rush away from police after picking through a store downtown plunder stores as protestors face off with police as unrest continues in the wake of the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Officials fear protests are 'super-spreader' events for coronavirus. Marchers say worth the risk
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes, Soumya Karlamangla
item.description: Officials fear protests are 'super-spreader' events for coronavirus. Marchers say worth the risk
item.content:encoded: Officials fear protests are 'super-spreader' events for coronavirus. Marchers say worth the risk

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 31: Protesters raise their arms chanting "Hands up, don't shoot!" during a protest at Pershing Square in downtown Los Angeles on Sunday, May 31, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. About 400 protesters took part to draw attention to the death of George Floyd and Black Lives Matter. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Column: We are all horrified, but only white people have the luxury of being shocked
item.dc:creator: Mary McNamara
item.description: White people who want to be allies need to worry less about the George Floyd protests and more about the systemic racism that sparked them.
item.content:encoded: White people who want to be allies need to worry less about the George Floyd protests and more about the systemic racism that sparked them.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CALIFORNIA MAY 31, 2020-Protestors embrace as another is led away in handcuffs on 5th St. in Santa Maonica Sunday. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A., wracked by looting and upheaval, turns yet again to the National Guard
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Monte Morin, Thomas Curwen
item.description: The National Guard was deployed in L.A. during periods of unrest in 1965 and 1992, and after the Northridge earthquake in 1994. On Sunday, Humvees rolled through downtown after Mayor Eric Garcetti requested 1,000 troops.
item.content:encoded: The National Guard was deployed in L.A. during periods of unrest in 1965 and 1992, and after the Northridge earthquake in 1994. On Sunday, Humvees rolled through downtown after Mayor Eric Garcetti requested 1,000 troops.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 31: The California National Guard is deployed at City Hall in downtown Los Angeles on Sunday, May 31, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: 'Who approved this?' Riders, officials criticize Metro's systemwide shutdown
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: L.A.'s transit system was shut down as protests raged Saturday night over concerns over employees' safety. One L.A. councilman called it "unconscionable."
item.content:encoded: L.A.'s transit system was shut down as protests raged Saturday night over concerns over employees' safety. One L.A. councilman called it "unconscionable."

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA MAY 29, 2020-An MTA bus is vandalized in Downtown Los Angeles Friday. Protestors marched across the nation after the death of George Floyd. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Nearly 1,200 arrested in L.A. County after protests, looting; curfew extended
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Faith E. Pinho, James Queally, Melissa Etehad, Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: Amid George Floyd protests, looters emptied stores in Santa Monica and Long Beach. Several Los Angeles-area cities extended curfews after unrest.
item.content:encoded: Amid George Floyd protests, looters emptied stores in Santa Monica and Long Beach. Several Los Angeles-area cities extended curfews after unrest.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CALIFORNIA MAY 31, 2020-Looters grab merchandise at REI in Santa Maonica Sunday. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Skelton: To solve California's coronavirus-fueled budget woes, Newsom should gamble on sports betting
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: Democratic Sen. Bill Dodd of Napa and Assemblyman Adam Gray of Merced are proposing that California finally legalize sports betting — as 23 other states have done — and reap several hundred million dollars annually in 'sin' taxes.
item.content:encoded: Democratic Sen. Bill Dodd of Napa and Assemblyman Adam Gray of Merced are proposing that California finally legalize sports betting — as 23 other states have done — and reap several hundred million dollars annually in 'sin' taxes.

media:content.media:description: Amado Nanalang watches basketball games while making bets at a sports book in Las Vegas.

item.title: Man shot to death in downtown Los Angeles amid protests Sunday
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth, Richard Winton
item.description: A man was shot to death Sunday evening, according to the Los Angeles Police Department, a killing committed in an area of downtown Los Angeles that was flooded with protesters decrying police brutality.
item.content:encoded: A man was shot to death Sunday evening, according to the Los Angeles Police Department, a killing committed in an area of downtown Los Angeles that was flooded with protesters decrying police brutality.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - MAY 30, 2020. Police officers stand outside a looted store on Broadway in downtown Los Angeles on Saturday, May 30, 2020. About 200 people marched through downtown streets, slowing traffic and keeping ahead of police trying to cut them off. Looting and the destruction of public and private property has spread across the country in the wake of the the police killing of George Floyd, a black man in Minneapolis. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Thousands of cars protest in caravan through Oakland
item.dc:creator: Johana Bhuiyan
item.description: A procession of thousands of cars snaked through Oakland on Sunday to demand justice for the killing of George Floyd in Minnesota.
item.content:encoded: A procession of thousands of cars snaked through Oakland on Sunday to demand justice for the killing of George Floyd in Minnesota.

media:content.media:description: A car participates in a caravan protest in Oakland on Sunday.

item.title: L.A. County courts are ordered closed Monday due to protests
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: All Los Angeles County court proceedings will be suspended through at least Monday in response to ongoing protests.
item.content:encoded: All Los Angeles County court proceedings will be suspended through at least Monday in response to ongoing protests.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 18, 2017 -- The Stanley Mosk Courthouse, which is the main civil courthouse of the Superior Court of Los Angeles County in downtown Los Angeles on May 18, 2017. California's court leaders expressed alarm Wednesday over a new study that showed more than 100 courthouses in the state - including many in Los Angeles County - could collapse and cause "substantial" loss of life in a major earthquake. Courthouses near the top of the list of buildings in peril include the Stanley Mosk Courthouse and Clara Shortridge Foltz Criminal Justice Center, the Pasadena municipal courthouse, and courthouses in Beverly Hills and Burbank. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 13 arrested in attempt to loot Lakewood mall, sheriff says
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: Sheriff's deputies were out in force at the shopping center, and Sheriff Alex Villanueva said they were able to quickly control the situation.
item.content:encoded: Sheriff's deputies were out in force at the shopping center, and Sheriff Alex Villanueva said they were able to quickly control the situation.

item.title: Melrose Avenue, one of L.A.'s hippest streets, hit hard by looters
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia, Joseph Serna, Laura Newberry
item.description: Business owners on Melrose Avenue in the Fairfax District were forced to take stock Sunday after a night of civil unrest gave way to mayhem.
item.content:encoded: Business owners on Melrose Avenue in the Fairfax District were forced to take stock Sunday after a night of civil unrest gave way to mayhem.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-MAY 31, 2020: A storefront on Melrose Avenue is shattered on Sunday, May 31, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD officer is shot in the leg at Whole Foods parking lot in Venice
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: The incident occurred about 4:30 p.m. in the area of the Whole Foods parking lot near Lincoln Boulevard and Rose Avenue.
item.content:encoded: The incident occurred about 4:30 p.m. in the area of the Whole Foods parking lot near Lincoln Boulevard and Rose Avenue.

media:content.media:description: An LAPD patrol car rushes through the intersection of La Brea Avenue and Venice Boulevard in April.

item.title: Shyong: What images of burning buildings and broken windows tell us, and what they don't
item.dc:creator: Frank Shyong
item.description: People tend to look for answers after a fire, but we're rarely satisfied by the ones we get.
item.content:encoded: People tend to look for answers after a fire, but we're rarely satisfied by the ones we get.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CALIFORNIA MAY 31, 2020-A man runs the Sake House restaurant as it burns in the background in Santa Maonica Sunday. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.dc:creator: Ruben Vives, Hannah Fry
item.description: As protesters demonstrated against police abuse on Ocean Boulevard in Long Beach on Sunday, some looters hit a nearby shopping center.
item.content:encoded: As protesters demonstrated against police abuse on Ocean Boulevard in Long Beach on Sunday, some looters hit a nearby shopping center.

item.title: In the heart of Santa Ana, residents clean up and debate after protest
item.dc:creator: Gustavo Arellano
item.description: In Orange County, the city of Santa Ana spurs conflicting emotions.
item.content:encoded: In Orange County, the city of Santa Ana spurs conflicting emotions.

media:content.media:description: Arthur Borboa, 33, cleans up debris outside the Bristol Swap Mall in Santa Ana, the morning after a protest

item.title: Scene of unchecked looting sparks anger: 'It was like a McDonald's drive-through'
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, Kim Christensen
item.description: Authorities did not have a tally of how many businesses were vandalized or robbed, but parts of Fairfax Avenue and Melrose Avenue were hard hit, with dozens of storefronts damaged.
item.content:encoded: Authorities did not have a tally of how many businesses were vandalized or robbed, but parts of Fairfax Avenue and Melrose Avenue were hard hit, with dozens of storefronts damaged.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -- MAY 30: Looters and vandals ransack Spokes 'N Stuff at Melrose Ave. and Ogden Dr. in the Melrose District on Saturday, May 30, 2020, in Los Angeles, CA. Several businesses on Melrose Avenue, a trendy row of design and clothing stores, were looted. Earlier in the day protestors demonstrated at the corner of Fairfax and 3rd Street in response to the death of George Floyd in Minnesota. More than 500 arrests after looting and vandalism sweep downtown L.A. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Chicago natives shocked by violence and looting in L.A.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Serna, Kim Christensen
item.description: The Melrose residents say that although looters were of every race and ethnicity, their actions will only reinforce negative stereotypes, making it harder for black people like them.
item.content:encoded: The Melrose residents say that although looters were of every race and ethnicity, their actions will only reinforce negative stereotypes, making it harder for black people like them.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -- MAY 30: Shop owners assess the damage after looters and vandals ransacked businesses along Melrose Ave. in the Melrose District on Saturday, May 30, 2020, in Los Angeles, CA. Several businesses on Melrose Avenue, a trendy row of design and clothing stores, were looted. Earlier in the day protestors demonstrated at the corner of Fairfax and 3rd Street in response to the death of George Floyd in Minnesota. More than 500 arrests after looting and vandalism sweep downtown L.A. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Recalling '92 riots, Von Dutch general manager tells staff to leave Melrose store
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: The Von Dutch North America general manager was in the L.A. area during the 1992 riots. He wanted staff to be safe during the George Floyd protests.
item.content:encoded: The Von Dutch North America general manager was in the L.A. area during the 1992 riots. He wanted staff to be safe during the George Floyd protests.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA MAY 30, 2020-A firefighter walks behind a building on fire on Melrose Avenue during civil unrest in Los Angeles Saturday. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde, Melissa Etehad
item.description: Santa Monica extended its curfew, from 8 p.m. Sunday to 5:30 a.m. Monday. Protesters of George Floyd's death marched peacefully through the city.
item.content:encoded: Santa Monica extended its curfew, from 8 p.m. Sunday to 5:30 a.m. Monday. Protesters of George Floyd's death marched peacefully through the city.

item.title: Looters even steal ice cube trays from freezer at Melrose store amid protests
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: The store had reopened Friday after being closed due to the coronavirus outbreak. But it closed its doors Saturday because of George Floyd protests.
item.content:encoded: The store had reopened Friday after being closed due to the coronavirus outbreak. But it closed its doors Saturday because of George Floyd protests.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-MAY 31, 2020: Shattered glass sits in a storefront on Melrose Avenue as passers by access the damage on Sunday, May 31, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: She watched livestream of her Melrose shop being looted: 'Please don't light it on fire'
item.dc:creator: Joseph Serna, Brittny Mejia
item.description: Melrose shop owner Lindsay Pierce watched on security cameras as three men darted inside her store and cut the store internet router, severing her connection.

item.content:encoded: Looters and vandals ransacked several businesses on Los Angeles' Melrose Avenue, a trendy row of clothing stores.

Earlier in the day protestors demonstrated at the corner of Fairfax and 3rd Street in response to the death of George Floyd in Minnesota. item.title: Protests in Northern California are marked by frustration and pockets of violence
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: As the National Guard was called to Los Angeles on Saturday night, protesters continued clashing with police in Oakland, San Francisco and Sacramento.
item.content:encoded: As the National Guard was called to Los Angeles on Saturday night, protesters continued clashing with police in Oakland, San Francisco and Sacramento.

media:content.media:description: A police officer aims his weapon while clearing a vandalized Victoria's Secret store in San Francisco on Saturday, May 30, 2020. Widespread vandalizing occurred at stores throughout San Francisco following the death of George Floyd, a handcuffed black man in police custody in Minneapolis. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

item.title: Despite curfew, downtown L.A. hit by more looting overnight
item.dc:creator: Monte Morin, Tania Ganguli
item.description: National Guard troops deployed onto the streets of downtown Los Angeles after Gov. Gavin Newsom declared a state of emergency.
item.content:encoded: National Guard troops deployed onto the streets of downtown Los Angeles after Gov. Gavin Newsom declared a state of emergency.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - MAY 30, 2020. Protesters break windows along Figueroa Street in downtown Los Angeles on Saturday, May 30, 2020. About 200 people marched through downtown streets, slowing traffic and keeping ahead of police trying to cut them off. Looting and the destruction of public and private property has spread across the country in the wake of the the police killing of George Floyd, a black man in Minneapolis. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Sometimes peaceful is not enough': L.A. protesters explain why they hit the streets
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith, Emily Baumgaertner, Leila Miller
item.description: Thousands of demonstrators swarmed the Fairfax District on Saturday, protesting the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis.
item.content:encoded: Thousands of demonstrators swarmed the Fairfax District on Saturday, protesting the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis.

item.title: Boardwalk closed. University closed. Santa Cruz met the moment, but at a huge cost
item.dc:creator: Melissa Gomez
item.description: Santa Cruz's economy is built around seasonal tourism and the UC Santa Cruz. Businesses are starting to reopen, but staying safe depends on how the county can manage an influx of visitors.
item.content:encoded: Santa Cruz's economy is built around seasonal tourism and the UC Santa Cruz. Businesses are starting to reopen, but staying safe depends on how the county can manage an influx of visitors.

media:content.media:description: SANTA CRUZ, CA -- MAY 22: Rick Tracewell, left, and partner Debi Tipple, both of Sacramento, are asked to leave Main Beach by the Santa Cruz Police Ranger on Friday, May 22, 2020, in Santa Cruz, CA. Santa Cruz has successfully bent the curve of cases and deaths from COVID-19 after sheltering in place early. The beaches will be closed from 11:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., daily until further notice. The ocean will remain open for water sports (e.g., surfing, boogie-boarding, swimming, paddle-boarding, kayaking, boating, etc.), and individuals may cross beaches in order to access and leave the ocean. All other non-exercise, passive, or sedentary activities at beaches, such as sitting, lying, standing, picnicking, etc, are prohibited. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Churches plan big Pentecost services despite orders: 'It's part of our faith to be together'
item.dc:creator: Sarah Parvini
item.description: What began as a public health debate has quickly escalated into a dispute over freedom of worship in several states.
item.content:encoded: What began as a public health debate has quickly escalated into a dispute over freedom of worship in several states.

media:content.media:description: FONTANA, CA - MAY 30, 2020: Donald and Angie Autrey of Rancho Cucamonga pray before services begin at the reopening of the Water of Life Community Church during the coronavirus pandemic on May 30, 2020 in Fontana, California. The chairs have been covered in plastic and spaced out for social distancing. The stadium seating will not be used only the floor seating at 20% capacity. The plastic will be thrown out and new plastic used for each service.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. reels from looting and arrests not seen in decades
item.dc:creator: Ruben Vives, Dakota Smith
item.description: The unrest in L.A. has some longtime residents recalling the violence that took place in 1992 after four LAPD officers were acquitted in the Rodney King beating.
item.content:encoded: The unrest in L.A. has some longtime residents recalling the violence that took place in 1992 after four LAPD officers were acquitted in the Rodney King beating.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CALIFORNIA MAY 31, 2020-Looters grab merchandise at REI in Santa Maonica Sunday. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'It's all over the board.' California still far from testing everyone in elder care homes
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria, Maya Lau
item.description: State officials want more coronavirus testing in nursing homes
item.content:encoded: State officials want more coronavirus testing in nursing homes

media:content.media:description: SACRAMENTO, CA-MAY 22, 2020: Sacramento County health director Peter Beilenson, 60, visits his mother, Dolores Beilenson, 86, at Sunrise of Sacramento, an assisted living center, where she has resided for the past year. Because of the coronavirus outbreak, no visitors are allowed inside the living center. Dolores tested positive for COVID-19 at the end of March and tested negative 3 weeks later. Peter has been managing the coronavirus outbreak for the county. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column One: A coronavirus commune with 16 people? 'Who's to say we're not family?'
item.dc:creator: Maria L. La Ganga
item.description: The plan started simply enough. As the pandemic forced schools to shutter in March, three families in Riverside banded together to make sure all their children kept learning.
item.content:encoded: The plan started simply enough. As the pandemic forced schools to shutter in March, three families in Riverside banded together to make sure all their children kept learning.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CA- MAY 5, 2020: The students of "Brothbush Academy" cheer for their home school on the Roth's front lawn in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic on May 5, 2020 in Riverside, California. From the left; Kat Bristow, Andie Bristow, Rosie Roth, Allison Furbush, Penelope Roth, Sylvester Roth, Carmen Furbush, and Ellie Bristow. The Bristow's, Roth's and Furbush's, who are also neighbors, have quarantined together and are home schooling the 8 children amongst them using the parents as teachers. They've named the school "Brothbush Academy" coined from the families' last names.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Looting hits Long Beach, Santa Monica as countywide curfew goes into effect
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde, Brittny Mejia, Joseph Serna, Ruben Vives, Melissa Etehad, Matthew Ormseth, Hailey Branson-Potts
item.description: The L.A. County curfew was put in place after looting and arson amid peaceful George Floyd protests. The National Guard and police officers were out.
item.content:encoded: The L.A. County curfew was put in place after looting and arson amid peaceful George Floyd protests. The National Guard and police officers were out.

media:content.media:description: Santa Monica, CA, Sunday May 31, 2020 - Protestors face off with police downtown as unrest continues in the wake of the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: San Francisco orders curfews, wants National Guard on standby after looting

item.content:encoded: San Francisco orders curfews, asks to have National Guard on standby after looting

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - MAY 30, 2020. Motorists go on a jjoyride down Main Street in downtown Los Angeles despite an 8 p.m. curfew on Saturday, May 30, 2020. About 200 people marched through downtown streets, slowing traffic and keeping ahead of police trying to cut them off. Looting and the destruction of public and private property has spread across the country in the wake of the the police killing of George Floyd, a black man in Minneapolis. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Two of L.A.'s hippest streets — Melrose and Fairfax — become targets for looters
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller, Emily Baumgaertner
item.description: "It's going to be like the Watts riots," one witness said. "I wasn't really alive for it, but I was alive for this one. I'll tell my kids and family members what happened."
item.content:encoded: "It's going to be like the Watts riots," one witness said. "I wasn't really alive for it, but I was alive for this one. I'll tell my kids and family members what happened."

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA MAY 30, 2020-Two women hug each other knowing they will be arrested along with protestors on Fairfax Ave. in Los Angeles Saturday. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Beverly Hills, West Hollywood prepare for protests, impose curfews
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, Dakota Smith
item.description: Beverly Hills officials have urged residents to stay indoors in preparation for protests, and West Hollywood's mayor said that city plans to issue a curfew for 8 p.m. through the 5:30 a.m. Beverly Hills is also ordering a curfew.
item.content:encoded: Beverly Hills officials have urged residents to stay indoors in preparation for protests, and West Hollywood's mayor said that city plans to issue a curfew for 8 p.m. through the 5:30 a.m. Beverly Hills is also ordering a curfew.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 30: People at a gathering setup by groups Black Lives Matter Los Angeles and Build Power at Pan Pacific Park on Saturday, May 30, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Protests erupted across the country, with people outraged over the death of George Floyd, a black man killed after a white Minneapolis police officer pinned him to the ground with his knee. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Federal officer killed by gunfire outside U.S. courthouse in Oakland
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth

item.content:encoded: One federal officer was fatally shot and another injured Friday in Oakland, authorities said, but it wasn't immediately clear if the incident was related to the night's protests.

item.title: Newsom's budget cuts would hit Californians most vulnerable to coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Samantha Young
item.description: Safety-net programs that keep low-income Californians out of nursing homes are on the chopping block with Gov. Gavin Newsom's proposed budget, aimed at plugging a massive deficit.
item.content:encoded: Safety-net programs that keep low-income Californians out of nursing homes are on the chopping block with Gov. Gavin Newsom's proposed budget, aimed at plugging a massive deficit.

media:content.media:description: Shirley Madden depends on help from Felix Valbuena to live independently at home in Chatsworth, California. Gov. Gavin Newsom's proposed state budget would reduce the number of hours caregivers can work under the state's In-Home Supportive Services program.

item.title: 'It's worse today than it was back then': Watching Minneapolis, some Angelenos recall Rodney King
item.dc:creator: Sonja Sharp
item.description: For millions who've watched it since Monday, George Floyd's final plea to the Minneapolis police officer now charged with his murder was an echo of Eric Garner's dying words: "I can't breathe."
item.content:encoded: For millions who've watched it since Monday, George Floyd's final plea to the Minneapolis police officer now charged with his murder was an echo of Eric Garner's dying words: "I can't breathe."

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, Thursday, May 28, 2020 - Elyssa Wells yells out protesting the death of George Floyd as she sits with others on Grand Ave., downtown, defying police orders to leave the area. The group finally dispersed after LAPD officers moved to clear the streets. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Schools issue warning: Coronavirus testing and tracing are needed before campuses reopen
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Sonali Kohli
item.description: coronavirus: California's largest school districts say fall reopening requires testing, contact tracing and more funding
item.content:encoded: coronavirus: California's largest school districts say fall reopening requires testing, contact tracing and more funding

media:content.media:description: GLENDALE, CA - MAY 26: Glendale Unified Supt. Vivian Ekchian, left, and Los Angeles County Office of Education Supt. Debra Duardo, right, are given a tour of Cerritos Elementary in Glendale by Principal Perla Chavez-Fritz, center, on Tuesday May 26, 2020 considering that with a persisting coronavirus threat, K-12 campuses will try to reopen in the fall. New L.A. County guidelines offer a possible roadmap but it could get complicated and costly to confront the logistics of reopening at an actual school in the wake of Covid-19. Glendale on Tuesday, May 26, 2020 in Glendale, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: As our world reopens, can I trust you to keep me safe from the coronavirus?

item.content:encoded: Trust is key as we reopen with the coronavirus still present

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA -- SATURDAY, APRIL 25, 2020: With beach parking lots closed down, crowds of people cross Pacific Coast Highway to and from the beach as they join thousands of beach-goers enjoy a warm, sunny day at the beach amid state-mandated stay-at-home and social distancing mandate to stave off the coronavirus pandemic in Huntington Beach, CA, on April 25, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Tim

item.content:encoded: L.A. County can reopening restaurants, hair salons

On Friday, Los Angeles County received permission to reopen restaurants for in-person dining and resume services at barbershops and hair salons, marking a new phase in the regions efforts to restart the devastated retail economy. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 29: Protestors face off with a large law enforcement presence in downtown Los Angeles on Friday, May 29, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Friday evening saw yet another date of protests with people outraged over the the death of George Floyd, a black man killed after a white Minneapolis police officer pinned him to the ground with his knee. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: O.C. health officer receives threats over face covering mandate

item.content:encoded: Orange County Board of Supervisors Chair Michelle Steel condemned what she deemed to be a death threat against County Health Officer Dr. Nichole Quick this week.

media:content.media:description: GRASS VALLEY, MAY 21, 2020: Dawn Krawczyk, a sales floor manager at Yuba Blue, a women's clothing store in Grass Valley, uses steam to disinfect a romper, before placing it back on the rack. The store recently re-opened after being forced to close due to the coronavirus outbreak. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: San Diego to allow sunbathing, other passive beach activities
item.dc:creator: Lyndsay Winkley
item.description: The new regulations allow people in the same household to sit together on the sand. Activities like football and volleyball are still banned, and parking lots and piers remain closed.
item.content:encoded: The new regulations allow people in the same household to sit together on the sand. Activities like football and volleyball are still banned, and parking lots and piers remain closed.

media:content.media:description: SDPD at Ocean Beach used all-terrain vehicles to help inform and enforce county beach orders for "No Stopping No Sitting."
media:content.media:credit: Nelvin C. Cepeda/Nelvin C. Cepeda/The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: Ventura County to extend stay-at-home order while continuing to ease restrictions
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: The Ventura County directive, put in place to stem the coronavirus' spread, is set to expire Sunday. Health officials plan to extend it, but with further relaxations.
item.content:encoded: The Ventura County directive, put in place to stem the coronavirus' spread, is set to expire Sunday. Health officials plan to extend it, but with further relaxations.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA -- MAY 28: Mary Jasso-Brooks, of Ventura, with James, left, and Paige, walk along the surf at the beach on Thursday, May 28, 2020, in Ventura, CA. While many parks and beaches in Ventura County have been open for active use for weeks, Ventura city officials will begin to further ease restrictions at their outdoor spaces starting Friday. "Passive" activities such as sitting and sunbathing will be allowed "as long as the public maintains a safe physical distance of six feet and avoids congregating in large groups. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: The words of Lincoln, Truman and Reagan got us through crises. Trump's words makes everything worse
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: FDR said, "repetition does not transform a lie into a truth." Trump has to hope that's not true.
item.content:encoded: FDR said, "repetition does not transform a lie into a truth." Trump has to hope that's not true.

media:content.media:description: Clockwise from top left; Painting of Gen. George Washington leads in the battle at Princeton, Jan. 3, 1777; an oil painting of Thomas Jefferson in 1805; 1865 photo of President Abraham Lincoln in Washington; President Donald Trump in the Oval Office; 1961 photo of President John F. Kennedy; and 1916 photo of President Woodrow Wilson throwing out ball at a baseball game in Washington.

item.title: Will small-business owners go to jail for breaking coronavirus rules? We'll find out
item.dc:creator: Margot Roosevelt
item.description: L.A. is prosecuting more than 70 businesses so far for allegedly flouting COVID-19 rules. The group includes pet groomers, salons and smoke shops.
item.content:encoded: L.A. is prosecuting more than 70 businesses so far for allegedly flouting COVID-19 rules. The group includes pet groomers, salons and smoke shops.

media:content.media:description: SHERMAN OAKS, CA-MAY 15, 2020: Janet Tavakoli, 69, owner of Sherman Oaks Beauty Collection, wearing a protective mask against the coronavirus, is photographed next to bottles of hand sanitizer, right, for sale inside her store. The store is one of 60 non-essential businesses cited by Los Angeles City Attorney Mike Feuer for "flouting the city's Safer at Home order. Tavakoli says she shut down her store for 2 weeks, losing $15,000 in sales but reopened after seeing beauty store competitors open. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Bald eagles return to nest in Orange County neighborhood
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: For the last three years, two bald eagles have been returning to nest in the backyard of a north O.C. home.
item.content:encoded: For the last three years, two bald eagles have been returning to nest in the backyard of a north O.C. home.

media:content.media:description: NORTH ORANGE COUNTY, CA - MAY 27: A tagged female of two parent bald eagles takes flight from a branch high in a tree not far from its nest in north Orange County containing two juvenile eagles Wednesday, May 27, 2020. The blue $85 tag indicates it is part of the Institute for Wildlife Studies project to rebuild the bald eagle population on the Channel Islands, was hatched in 2013 at Santa Rosa Island and given the name La'i. Neighbors say it's the third year the bald eagles have returned to the area to raise chicks. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times) (Please note: Do not to disclose the location of the nest so the bald eagles would not be disturbed.)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. County can reopen restaurants, barbershops, salons, Newsom says

item.content:encoded: L.A. County, the epicenter of California's coronavirus outbreak, can reopen restaurants for in-person dining and resume services at hairstyling shops.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 18, 2020 Grace Curran, restaurant manager wipes table tops with disinfectant at Republique (French Restaurant) located at 624 South La Brea as the restaurant continues to serve patrons who love the fine pastries in the morning with a full menu available for carry-out and delivery on Wednesday morning as the restaurant has changed its work flow to accommodate for the coronavirus limitations. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Sonoma County retreated on reopening. Now the sheriff will stop enforcing coronavirus orders
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Sheriff Mark Essick says his department will stop enforcing local shelter-in-place restrictions amid the coronavirus pandemic, even as cases rise.
item.content:encoded: Sheriff Mark Essick says his department will stop enforcing local shelter-in-place restrictions amid the coronavirus pandemic, even as cases rise.

media:content.media:description: In this photo taken Wednesday, April 1, 2020, are the empty grounds of the historic Buena Vista Winery in Sonoma, Calif. Wineries that want to stay viable and connected to their customers during the coronavirus pandemic are harnessing platforms such as Facebook Live to offer virtual wine experiences. Tasting rooms in California shut down last month after the governor ordered businesses to close to slow the spread of the new virus. (AP Photo/Eric Risberg)

item.title: Offer of masks for California drew a cast of characters, from a lobbyist to an ex-con
item.dc:creator: Adam Elmahrek, Melody Gutierrez

item.content:encoded: A deal that never materialized to sell tens of millions of masks to the state government offers a rare behind-the-scenes view into the masks trade.

media:content.media:description: Some health care experts recommend the use of N95 respirator masks to help protect against wildfire smoke. Simple dust or surgical masks do not offer the same kind of protection, they warn. (Ana B. Ibarra/California Healthline)

item.content:encoded: Protesters blocked traffic and threw rocks at businesses and passing cars, authorities said, damaging windows at Fontana City Hall.

item.title: Whites far less likely to die from the coronavirus than blacks, Latinos in L.A. County

item.content:encoded: The death rate in Los Angeles County is far greater for Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander, black and Latino residents than for white people, data show.

media:content.media:description: INGLEWOOD-CA-APRIL 15, 2020: Clarice Kavanaugh places a hand on her friend Charles Jackson's casket at Inglewood Park Cemetery in Inglewood on Wednesday, April 15, 2020. Jackson was diagnosed with covid-19 after returning home from a black ski trip in Idaho, and died days later in the hospital. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California surpasses 4,000 coronavirus deaths, with L.A. County hardest hit
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Luke Money, Maura Dolan, Jaclyn Cosgrove

item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County recorded 50 new deaths Friday, a number that pushed the overall death toll in California past 4,000.

item.title: Reopening California off to a slow start as customers stay away, fears of coronavirus still loom large
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Andrew J. Campa, Maria L. La Ganga, Doug Smith
item.description: The gradual reopening underscores the difficult choice facing retailers, employees and consumers alike: If stores are full, the pandemic could worsen. If they're empty, there goes the economy.
item.content:encoded: The gradual reopening underscores the difficult choice facing retailers, employees and consumers alike: If stores are full, the pandemic could worsen. If they're empty, there goes the economy.

media:content.media:description: GLENDALE, CA - MAY 28: Wearing masks/face covering and practicing social distancing, people wander the Glendale Galleria on Thursday, May 28, 2020 in Glendale, CA. The Glendale Galleria which has been shuttered to help fight the spread of the novel coronavirus, COVID19, was open today as a result of Gov. Gavin Newsom's easing of requirements for reopening businesses. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Chinese billionaire helped L.A. councilman settle sexual harassment suit, feds say
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: Court documents in the George Esparza case allege that a billionaire Chinese real estate developer played a crucial role in helping L.A. Councilman Jose Huizar settle a sexual harassment lawsuit as he was seeking re-election.
item.content:encoded: Court documents in the George Esparza case allege that a billionaire Chinese real estate developer played a crucial role in helping L.A. Councilman Jose Huizar settle a sexual harassment lawsuit as he was seeking re-election.

media:content.media:description: A Feb. 15, 2012, photo of Los Angeles City Councilman Jose Huizar and a Jan. 8, 2010, image of his then-deputy chief of staff, Francine Godoy. Huizar has denied allegations in a complaint against him by Godoy.

item.title: Supreme Court rejects challenge to California limits on church crowds during pandemic
item.dc:creator: David G. Savage
item.description: Supreme Court rules in a case in which a San Diego-area church challenged Gov. Gavin Newsom's order limiting attendance because of the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Supreme Court rules in a case in which a San Diego-area church challenged Gov. Gavin Newsom's order limiting attendance because of the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: The U.S. Supreme Court building in Washington.

item.title: California's coronavirus budget crisis leaves Newsom and lawmakers at odds
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: The alternative budget adopted by Senate Democrats differs from the governor's proposal to address the state's coronavirus fueled deficit in several key ways.
item.content:encoded: The alternative budget adopted by Senate Democrats differs from the governor's proposal to address the state's coronavirus fueled deficit in several key ways.

media:content.media:description: John Gibbins U-T Gov. Gavin Newsom and State Senate President Pro Tempore Toni Atkins at the San Diego 211 center.

item.title: Los Angeles County public defender dies from COVID-19
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton
item.description: It marked the first coronavirus death in the ranks of the L.A. County public defender's office, and it comes as courts across California chart a path to reopen services and ease restrictions.
item.content:encoded: It marked the first coronavirus death in the ranks of the L.A. County public defender's office, and it comes as courts across California chart a path to reopen services and ease restrictions.

item.title: Protesters return to downtown Los Angeles to decry police killing in Minneapolis
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: The demonstration, organized by the Los Angeles chapter of Black Lives Matter, was on a smaller scale than the day before.
item.content:encoded: The demonstration, organized by the Los Angeles chapter of Black Lives Matter, was on a smaller scale than the day before.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 28, 2020: A protester tosses a bottled water on a CHP vehicle as other Black Lives Matter protesters swarm the car in a rally in front of LAPD headquarters to protest the death of George Floyd during the coronavirus pandemic on May 28, 2020 in Los Angeles, California. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: More than 60 Imperial County coronavirus patients are being treated at Riverside County hospitals
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: More than 60 Imperial County coronavirus patients are being treated in Riverside County due to a hospital surge.
item.content:encoded: More than 60 Imperial County coronavirus patients are being treated in Riverside County due to a hospital surge.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CA- APRIL 8, 2020: Medical staff carry a patient's belongings as she is evacuated from Magnolia Rehabilitation and Nursing Center after 39 tested positive for coronavirus and the nursing staff was not showing up to work for their own safety on April 8, 2020 in Riverside, California. All 84 resident patients will be removed to other facilities.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County officials hope reopening plan is approved by Friday
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove, Colleen Shalby
item.description: Los Angeles County officials are hoping to find out as early as Friday whether they'll be allowed to reopen restaurants for in-person dining, along with barbershops and hair salons.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County officials are hoping to find out as early as Friday whether they'll be allowed to reopen restaurants for in-person dining, along with barbershops and hair salons.

media:content.media:description: GLENDALE, CA - MAY 28: Signs that say Dick's Sporting Goods is open are seen as people wearing masks/face covering and practicing social distancing wander the Glendale Galleria on Thursday, May 28, 2020 in Glendale, CA. The Glendale Galleria which has been shuttered to help fight the spread of the novel coronavirus, COVID19, was open today as a result of Gov. Gavin Newsom's easing of requirements for reopening businesses. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Garcetti, Martinez call on L.A. City Councilman Huizar to resign
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith
item.description: L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti and City Council President Nury Martinez called on Councilman Jose Huizar to resign amid an ongoing federal investigation into a City Hall "pay-to-play" scandal. Huizar has not been charged.
item.content:encoded: L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti and City Council President Nury Martinez called on Councilman Jose Huizar to resign amid an ongoing federal investigation into a City Hall "pay-to-play" scandal. Huizar has not been charged.

media:content.media:description: 14th District council member Jose Huizar.

item.title: Yolo County ditches its local shelter in place order, but state order remains
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo
item.description: Yolo County has lifted its local coronavirus shelter in place order, but the state order remains in effect
item.content:encoded: Yolo County has lifted its local coronavirus shelter in place order, but the state order remains in effect

media:content.media:description: This transmission electron microscope image shows SARS-CoV-2, also known as 2019-nCoV, the coronavirus virus that causes COVID-19
media:content.media:credit: (National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases Rocky Mountain Laboratories)

item.title: San Clemente removes controversial beach fencing amid pressure from county sheriff
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Access will be a little easier for beachgoers visiting San Clemente this week after city leaders voted to reopen parking lots and remove fencing that prompted community outcry and a stern rebuke from the county's top law enforcement official.
item.content:encoded: Access will be a little easier for beachgoers visiting San Clemente this week after city leaders voted to reopen parking lots and remove fencing that prompted community outcry and a stern rebuke from the county's top law enforcement official.

media:content.media:description: SAN CLEMENTE, CA - MAY 18: Families practice social distancing while playing in the water and sand near the San Clemente Pier on Monday, May 18, 2020 in San Clemente, CA. Orange County beaches are currently open for active recreation, which includes swimming, surfing, and running. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Travel ban lifted in El Dorado County but Lake Tahoe tourism still prohibited
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo
item.description: El Dorado County lifted its nonessential travel ban Wednesday but state officials will keep Lake Tahoe off limits
item.content:encoded: El Dorado County lifted its nonessential travel ban Wednesday but state officials will keep Lake Tahoe off limits

media:content.media:description: A report released this week finds that Lake Tahoe's water clarity declined slightly last year, but the overall trend remains positive.
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Synagogues in L.A. can reopen, but many rabbis are holding off
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Synagogues in L.A. are now allowed to reopen, but rabbis have been grappling with the right thing to do.
item.content:encoded: Synagogues in L.A. are now allowed to reopen, but rabbis have been grappling with the right thing to do.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA-MAY 28, 2020: Even though Young Israel of Century City synagogue on Pico Blvd. in Los Angeles has permission from the city and county of Los Angeles to reopen in a limited fashion, it's rabbi has firmly decided to hold off. Rabbi Elazar Muskin is among a group of local Orthodox rabbis who have signed a letter stating they will wait at least two weeks to see whether coronavirus cases surge upwards. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: San Francisco to allow outdoor dining, exercise classes and spectator-free sports in coming weeks
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: San Francisco will allow outdoor dining, exercise classes and spectator-free sports in the coming weeks.
item.content:encoded: San Francisco will allow outdoor dining, exercise classes and spectator-free sports in the coming weeks.

media:content.media:description: SAN FRANCISCO: The Golden State Warriors are in Oakland, but those in the know stay in S.F. Pictured: Evening commuters make their way across the Bay Bridge as a storm passes behind the San Francisco skyline as seen from Yerba Buena Island.
